verses.verse: ((1 A grievous complaint of the faithful, sore afflicted by sickness, persecutions and adversity,7 Being as it were left of God without any consolation.13 Yet he calleth on God by faith, and striveth against desperation.18 Complaining himself to be forsaken of all earthly help.) O Lord God of my salvation, I cry day and night (Though many cry in their sorrows, yet they cry not earnestly to God for remedy, as he did whom he confessed to be the author of his salvation.) before thee.
Let my prayer enter into thy presence: incline thine ear unto my cry.
For my soul is filled with evils, and my life draweth near to the grave.
I am counted among them that go down unto the pit, and am as a man without strength,

(For he that is dead, is free from all cares and business of this life: and thus he saith, because he was unprofitable for all matters concerning man’s life, and as it were cut off from this world.) Free among the dead, like the slain laying in the grave, when thou rememberest no more, and they are cut off from thy (That is, from thy providence and care, which is meant according to the judgment of the flesh.) hand.
Thou hast laid me in the lowest pit, in darkness, and in the deep.
Thine indignation lieth upon me, and thou hast vexed me with all thy (The storms of thy wrath have overwhelmed me.) waves. Selah.

Thou hast put away mine (He attributeth the loss and displeasure of his friends to God’s providence, whereby he partly punisheth and partly trieth his.) acquaintance far from me, and made me to be abhorred of them: (I see none end of my sorrows.) I am shut up, and cannot get forth.
(Mine eyes and face declare my sorrows.) Mine eye is sorrowful through mine affliction: Lord, I call daily upon thee: I stretch out mine hands unto thee.

Wilt thou show (He showeth that the time is more convenient for God to help, when men call unto him in their dangers, than to tarry till they be dead, and then raise them up again.) a miracle to the dead? or shall the dead rise and praise thee? Selah.
Shall thy loving kindness be declared in the grave? or thy faithfulness in destruction?
Shall thy wondrous works be known in the dark? and thy righteousness in the land (That is, in the grave, where only the body lieth without all sense and remembrance.) of oblivion?
But unto thee, have I cried, O Lord, and early shall my prayer come before thee.
Lord, why dost thou reject my soul, and hidest thy face from me?
I am afflicted and at the point of death: (I am ever in great dangers and sorrows, as though my life should utterly be cut off every moment.) from my youth I suffer thy terrors, doubting of my life.
Thine indignations go over me, and thy fear hath cut me off.
They came round about me daily like water, and compassed me together.
My lovers and friends hast thou put away from me, and mine acquaintance (Hebrew, were in darkness.) hid themselves.
